name: places/ChIJnc2xl6NYwokRASZDcc_uCtY
formattedAddress: 1150 Park Ave, New York, NY 10128, USA
adrFormatAddress: 1150 Park Ave, New York, NY 10128-1244, USA

originalText.text: I went to see for a IME for an insurance company. Dr Bender demanded that I walk without my cane in his hallway and I told him I couldn’t nor would I as I would fall. He became very nasty as he continued his evaluation. When he generated his report he put down my gait was normal and I walked with an arm swing. Dr Bender lied on his report and I would WARN EVERYONE WHO READS THIS TO ALWAYS BRING A WITNESS. His loyalty is to the insurance company to the point that he would outright lie. There were other instances in his report that were more option than fact which I can understand. But to OUTRIGHT LIE ABOUT ME WALKING WHEN I HAD A LIMP SND A CANE IS OUTRIGHT CRIMINAL. BE VERY CAREFUL WITH THIS DR.   BRING A WITNESS.  DONT GO ALONE.

originalText.text:
Dr. Bender treats his money better than his patients. He exudes cold demeanor and projects an uncaring, indignant and apathetic attitude. On the day of my appointment I happened to have an excruciating nerve pain in the leg and because of it arrived minutes late for my appointment only to be turned away at the door! When I told him I was in severe pain and that it took me two hours to get to his office, and that I wouldn’t mind waiting to be seen later the same day, it fell on deaf ears. Not even the slightest sympathy. How can a neurologist be so callous towards people experiencing extreme neurological pain in his own office? Later I found out he still got paid for my missed appointment!
Medical ethics require that doctors treat people equally without any form of prejudice according to their medical needs. Not in this office. He looked at me, saw me writhing from pain and not only failed to offer any medical help but also threatened to call security if I didn’t leave?! Lesson learned, if someone needs a doctor in case of an emergency, like the one I had, not only this MD will not come forward to assist you but will make sure to humiliate, shame and blame it on you. It is time to take responsibility for your failed action as a medical professional Dr. Bender and not hide behind excuses for the sake of insurance companies. It is because of doctors like you this nation faces a health crisis where patients like me struggle with pain while doctors like you get paid watching them suffer, in their own office! Naive me, right?

originalText.text: Beware! Extremely unethical and disrespectful doctor. A wolf in sheep’s clothing: works for the benefit of insurance companies, not actual patients who suffer from pain. Gravely insulted my dad who happened to have an acute episode of severe neurological condition on the day he visited his office only to be turned away because he was late for 23 minutes due to the very pain he was suffering from that morning. Dr. Bender conveniently used the lateness by a sick patient to  excuse himself from examining my father as a reasonable doctor would have done. But he didn’t excuse himself from getting paid regardless how my father felt with his neurological condition. Just so you know Dr. Bender, my father now has been referred for an urgent surgery by another neurologist who cared to see him due to the same pain that decided to neglect and collect upon.

originalText.text: Dr. Bender provided excellent care for my headaches. His thoroughness and attention to detail was impressive, and he made sure to fully understand my symptoms before recommending a course of treatment. I appreciated his willingness to listen and answer all of my questions. Overall, I would highly recommend Dr. Bender for anyone seeking relief from headaches.

text.text: Dr. Bender provided excellent care for my headaches. His thoroughness and attention to detail was impressive, and he made sure to fully understand my symptoms before recommending a course of treatment. I appreciated his willingness to listen and answer all of my questions. Overall, I would highly recommend Dr. Bender for anyone seeking relief from headaches.

originalText.text:
This doctor is a crook. He mistreated my dear brother who visited his office while in pain. See my brother’s detailed account of what transpired in a review below, then read the doctor’s reply to my brother. For the lack a better word, the doctor’s reply shocks the conscience because instead of being professional and sympathetic to the cause, he doubles down and switches into defensive mode by stating that the “appointment wasn’t for treatment or diagnosis but a “medicolegal” exam”. It is evident that the doctor routinely diminishes the value of the so-called “medicolegal” exam. Goes without saying, he gets paid for each “missed” visit. Note that the doctor, in his review, withheld information that my brother was already in his office when he threatened to throw him out. No other medical professional would “throw a patient out” for being 23 minutes late for an appointment. Also, the doctor insinuates that my brother wasn’t his patient. This isn’t true. If a doctor is in a possession of one’s medical file (he had my brother’s file on hand), is expected to examine that person and then gets paid for it, that person becomes a patient by default or at least should be extended the same courtesy as any other patient receiving medical care.
It is without doubt such practice is utterly unethical because it effectively discriminates against “medicolegal” patients and results in them feeling disregarded and receiving inadequate medical attention. This doctor effectively converted my brother’s medically urgent, physically painful and emotionally humiliating experience into a normalized, passive-income scheme under the pretense of medical care shielded by convoluted legalese. Such practice empowers ethically-impoverished doctors to promote stereotyping and monetization of “medicolegal” patients by misleading them to believe they are about to receive equal treatment as other patients even for a 10- minute “medicolegal” exam. It is no different than a switch and bait scheme. It is in fact a predatory practice where a doctor takes advantage of a sick patient. It is nothing short of a legalized scam that enables Dr. Bender to arbitrarily choose whom to examine based on a single criterion of a 20-minute timeframe which automatically decides if one’s medical condition doesn’t warrant the same level of care as regular patients. That it’s ok to turn a blind eye, literally (my brother was pleading to be seen directly to Dr. Bender in person, in his office), on someone’s painful plight and withhold medical attention only because he has already been paid. This is one corrupt way to misuse a medical degree, if you ask me. Tell me if this isn’t crooked. Therefore, based on my brother’s painful and humiliating experience, I would not visit such doctor and certainly not recommend to anyone else as well.
